title: Microsoft returns to phone fold with folding phone
text:
"The lack of dedicated applications for tablet and exotic format Android devices is a real problem," Foad Fadaghi, managing director at the technology analysis outfit Telsyte, said.

Telsyte's research has found that sales of Android tablets are in "rapid decline" in Australia, mainly because they lack the dedicated large-screen apps on Apple's iPads.

That same problem would beset the Surface Duo, too, unless Microsoft can somehow come up with enough new apps to make people want to use large-screened Android devices, Mr Fadaghi said.

"A new form factor is always going to struggle to find the killer applications that make it successful . . . Who's going to develop dedicated apps, that make use of that two-screen real estate, for a very, very niche product?" he said.

"Can you see Microsoft spending time and resources itself developing apps for a niche version of someone else's platform?"

The phone will have a pen, allowing users to take handwritten notes like they can on a Samsung Galaxy Note.

In some ways, he said Microsoft would have been better off releasing another Windows phone, "or at least one that allowed users to utilise the Windows application ecosystem, which is massive. It's the key business application platform."

The timing of the Duo, coming just when phone users are beginning to question the value of expensive mobile phones, and are looking increasingly at mid-tier phones, is also going to be a problem for Microsoft, publisher at the mobile phone comparison site WhistleOut, Joe Hanlon, said.

Advertisement

"It's certainly a risky time for Microsoft to dive back into the phone market, and with a device like the Duo that is bound to be both expensive and will rely on novelty to generate interest in it," he said.

"We know consumers are already struggling to justify the high price of new phones, so you have to wonder how many will see the value in buying one with two screens."

One way to convince users to pay for another expensive phone would be to tie it in closely with other Surface devices that run Windows 10.

"It would be great to see Microsoft develop some meaningful connection between the Duo and Windows 10, so that using a 'Surface' phone feels like an extension of what you do on your laptop," Mr Hanlon said.

"Google does a decent job of this with apps like Chrome and Maps, but you can imagine that Microsoft could take this idea much further, given how many people still use Windows as their primary operating system."

Microsoft declined to comment on whether it was working to create such a symbiosis between Windows and the Surface Duo, but it has been working to do almost exactly that with the world's No. 1 phone maker, Samsung.

At the launch of Samsung's productivity-oriented Galaxy Note 10 in August, Microsoft chief executive Satya Nadella announced he had struck a deal with Samsung, under which photos and documents on the Note 10 would be synced with Windows PCs via Microsoft's OneDrive storage system.

As part of that deal, Note users also get a Microsoft application known as Link To Windows, which lets them integrate the Note directly into Windows on a PC when the two devices are joined by a USB cable.

With the Duo not due to be released for roughly a year – it's officially slated for "holiday 2020" – the company should have more than enough time to come up with the same tools for its own Android phone.
description: Microsoft spent billions acquiring Nokia, only to abandon the mobile phone business four years later. Now it's trying its luck with an Android phone.
